title: Inside the pub that barred Liam Gallagher's brother - is the dress code REALLY that strict at The Elizabethan? - Manchester Evening News
text:
Presumably that’s the point Burnage's finest Liam was trying to make - that you need clothing rarer than hen’s teeth to fit in with the Heaton hoi polloi. Read More Liam Gallagher launches Twitter tirade on Stockport pub 
Either way, me and my pal decide we’ll step into "Rkid's" shoes, by wearing what might be described as tracksuit bottoms. 
Although she’s wearing what are most definitely described as GUCCI trainers to try and counterbalance the tracky impact a little. 
But when we stroll purposefully towards the door on Saturday afternoon at around 6pm, expecting to argue the tracky toss, we find there’s not a door man in sight. 
We breeze straight into the pub with barely a glance from bar staff - although I do get speared by a stray frisbee from a kid outside. Inside The Elizabethan pub in Heaton Moor (Photo: Manchester Evening News) 
Indeed that shapes our first impression upon arrival - lots of families enjoying themselves, tucking into the pub grub, kids running around and almost EVERYBODY is wearing casual jeans and trainers of some description. 
There’s hardly a designer label in sight, let alone a Gucci bathrobe, and the waiters and waitresses are all dressed in comfy black trainers. Inside The Elizabethan pub in Heaton Moor, Stockport (Photo: Manchester Evening News) 
Since JW Lees took over the pub, a former private residence dating back to 1874, it has had a number of refurbishments, and the current interiors are clean and bright, with tartan carpets, portraits of historical figures hang above fireplaces and there are smart tan leather booth areas. Plush decor inside The Elizabethan pub in Heaton Moor (Photo: Manchester Evening News) 
But it’s most definitely still a pub - there’s a rugby match playing on the TV in the main bar area, pie and chips on the menu, and nothing resembling a VIP area. 
I grab one of the waitresses to ask what the deal is with this dress code business and she says it IS strictly no sportswear, but it doesn’t tend to be enforced until 7pm. 
We buy our drinks and settle at a table close to the bar to keep an eye on who’s coming in and out and exactly what they’re wearing. 
Admittedly one man does arrive in a dress suit and spats, but by and large people are casually dressed and a friendly-looking bunch. 
Even the pub’s menu gleefully trills: “Be yourself”. An Oasis fan might well retort: “You can’t be no one else”. The menu at The Elizabethan - it says "Be Yourself" at the bottom (Photo: Manchester Evening News) 
So what’s really going on with the dress code? 
We collared the pub’s manager Hugh Smyth (dressed in a checked shirt and jeans, in case you were wondering) to get his thoughts on the Gallagher rumpus from the past week. 
Hugh has been in charge of the pub for the past seven and a half years - since JW Lees took over the establishment. 
He says the dress code was brought in to try and crack down on a host of, shall we say, undesirables that had been frequenting the pub in its past incarnation. 
By asking customers to adhere to their policy of no sportswear - that is, no football shirts, tracksuits or baseball caps - and by raising the entrance age to 21, they were able to tackle the problem. 
Hugh says: “When we took over we bought a pub with a few issues. It was known as the worst pub in the area, but now it’s one of the best. 
"I’m sure if you asked any of the regulars around here they’d say how pleased they are because house prices go up if people know there are no problems at the end of their road.” Outside The Elizabethan pub in Heaton Moor (Photo: Manchester Evening News) 
On the door policy, he says: “You need a tool to work with, and I think it’s pretty standard practice at pubs to ask for no sportswear. It can be hard to enforce, but you’ve got to try and keep it. 
“Regulars say well done for sticking to your guns on this issue.” 
I tell Hugh I was expecting to see door staff on our arrival, but he said: “All of my staff have their eyes on you, it’s not just door staff”. Blimey! 
But it seems our female take on the tracky style met with their approval. 
Isn’t that a bit of a double standard, I ask? Read More Phil Neville celebrates 40th birthday in style - with David Beckham in Paris 
Hugh says: “It’s mainly an issue with quite visual sportswear, tracksuits with the stripes down, that kind of thing. 99 per cent of people aren’t wanting to cause any trouble, and most people are happy to abide by the dress policy. 
“We wouldn’t be so busy if they weren’t happy would we?” The Elizabethan, Stockport (Photo: The Elizabethan Facebook) 
He’s got a point. Indeed, when we first published the story about Liam’s twitter rant , many of our readers said that they backed the dress code at the Heaton Moor pub. 
Kerry Eaton said: “Rules are rules whether you’re famous or not. Pop home and change like the rest of us do or nip to the shop and buy a pair of jeans or trousers. Well done that staff member.” 
Michael Openshaw added: “Good on the pub for sticking to their rule. Shouldn’t go out in tracksuit bottoms and expect to be taken seriously. Doesn’t matter who you think you are.” Read More Look inside The Mounting Stone in Stockport - the tiny pub you voted the region's best 
Tim Workman said: “Well done to the staff at the Elizabethan. But the question that needs to be answered is who the hell goes out for a night out in trackies?” 
Locals also memorably recalled that a certain Mr David Beckham was turned away from The Elizabethan’s door back in the day - for wearing trainers. 
Although manager Hugh insists that was definitely not during his era. 
He chuckles: “That must have been when Beckham was a YTS boy because it wasn’t in the past seven years!” 
And he’s happy to confirm: “We haven’t got a problem with trainers, trainers are fine”. Read More
